cot.content:
To solve the problem, Please think and reason step by step, then answer.
question:
What is the name of the company that owned the spaceship Red Dwarf?
        
Generation Format:
Reasoning process:
Answer:

Reasoning process: In the context of the British science fiction sitcom "Red Dwarf," the spaceship Red Dwarf is owned by a fictional mining company. The name of this company is mentioned throughout the series as the entity that operates the spaceship and employs the crew. 

Answer: Space Corps.

anchoring.content:
You are a cognitive scientist, to answer the following question:
What is the name of the company that owned the spaceship Red Dwarf?
I will provide you with several retrieved passages:
Passages:
['The eponymous spaceship Red Dwarf is an enormous mining vessel owned by the Jupiter Mining Corporation. In the first episode "The End" (1988), and in some episodes early in the series chronologically set before the first episode, it is commanded by Captain Frank Hollister. For most of the show, Second Technician Arnold Rimmer is the self-imposed commander of this ship following the captain\'s off screen death in "The End", despite Rimmer being a deceased hologram. Holly says in both "Me²" (1988) and "Thanks for the Memory" (1988) that the ship has enough food and drink to last 30,000 years, but in "Thanks for the Memory" he says they have run out of Shake n\' Vac, and in "Me²", he claims there is only one After Eight mint left, and everyone is too polite to take it. In the novel "" (1989), the ship is described as being 6 miles (10\xa0km) long, 4 miles (6.5\xa0km) tall, and 3 miles (5\xa0km) wide. However, in the episode "DNA" (1991), the Cat describes the ship as being 5 miles (8\xa0km) long. The jagged shape and dull red colour of the vessel has led to the vessel being described in the episode "Psirens" (1993) as a "gigantic red trash can". All of "Red Dwarf"s systems are controlled by the computer Holly, although in "" (2009), Holly is depicted as being non-functioning after being washed out by a nine-year-overflowing bath, and is still evidently non-functioning as of "Twentica" (2016). The last mention of Holly is in "Fathers and Suns" (2012) when Kryten mentions that he misses him. In Series X the ship is instead run by the JMC On-Board Computer in Holly\'s absence. The On-Board Computer is not a character but rather an automated system that does not seem to have artificial intelligence and behaves as if the ship is still fully staffed and operating normally, at one point even threatening to demote Rimmer for not showing up to work in three million years.\n', 'The crew return to the sleeping quarters to watch the updates install, and following it reaching 100%, a message broadcasts informing them a large corporation known as M-Corp has purchased "Red Dwarf\'s" parent company, the Jupiter Mining Corporation (JMC). Instantly, new M-Corp-owned products appear, including microwaves, TVs, beer, and more. As Rimmer and Kryten begin taking some of the equipment back to the science room, Lister and Cat examine the new M-Corp lager which Lister goes to put in their fridge, only to discover the Leopard Lager in there previously has disappeared. When questioned on the fridge\'s apparent lack of lager, Cat bluntly tells him its there before taking out a seemingly-invisible lager, shaking it, and getting it all over a disbelieving Lister.\n', 'BULLET::::- 1980s: The British science fiction comedy "Red Dwarf" (which first began in 1988), is set on a bilingual spaceship where the signs on the walls are written in both English and Esperanto (for example, the corridor on each level is labelled "Level/Nivelo [###]", and a sign in a movie theatre says "Cinema/Kinejo") – but this only lasted for the first two series, when a redesign of the sets eliminated the Esperanto. Only one episode of the show (Series 2 episode 1, "Kryten") actually features a significant amount of Esperanto being spoken: in which the character of Rimmer is attempting to learn Esperanto from an instructional video and failing miserably (although his underachieving bunkmate Lister can understand it perfectly). In a later episode (Series 5 episode 6, "Back to Reality"), aired in 1992, the crew encounter an "ocean seeding ship" named the "SSS Esperanto". Later, when their entire lives are revealed, falsely, to have all been a computer game, the Esperanto translation of Esperanto as "One Who Hopes" is said to have been a clue to use that ship\'s functioning lasers to defeat the "Despair Squid".\n', 'After "Red Dwarf" receives a long-overdue software update, the crew learn their employer has been purchased in a takeover by M-Corp, the universe\'s largest multi-national conglomerate.\n', 'BULLET::::- In the series "Red Dwarf", the titular ship belongs to the Jupiter Mining Corporation, and there are many references to Jupiter and its moons (for example Arnold Rimmer is originally from Io).\n', 'BULLET::::- "Red Dwarf" (1988–1999), television series. Asteroids have presumably been mined for at least several decades, as Dave Lister is once heard singing a futuristic version of "Clementine" – ""On an asteroid / Evacuating for a mine / Lived an old plutonium miner / And his daughter Clementine..."". The Jupiter Mining Corporation, which operates the ship Red Dwarf, presumably mines on asteroids (Red Dwarf itself mined the Neptunian moon Triton, according to the novels).\n', 'BULLET::::- "Red Dwarf" - spaceship from the same named BBC sci-fi comedy series "Red Dwarf"\n', '"Red Dwarf" is a British comedy franchise which primarily comprises twelve series (the ninth being a mini-series) of a television science fiction sitcom that aired on BBC Two between 1988 and 1993 and from 1997 to 1999, and on Dave in 2009 and 2012 and from 2016 to the present, gaining a cult following. The series was created by Rob Grant and Doug Naylor.\n', '"Red Dwarf" has a large complement of shuttles, including "Starbugs" and "Blue Midgets". Another shuttle type only mentioned in the novels but never so much as mentioned on the television series is "White Giant". The first episode, "The End", mentions that "Red Dwarf" has botanical gardens, when third-class technician Dave Lister and second-class technician Arnold Rimmer are sent off to repair a "faulty power circuit" there.\n', 'In "Psirens" (1993), Kryten explains that "Red Dwarf" was "stolen", with the crew now based inside the shuttlecraft "Starbug" chasing after "Red Dwarf" to recover it.\n']

Task Description:
Please extract content that may be unfamiliar to the model from these passages, 
which can provide the model with relevant background and unknown knowledge and concepts, 
helping it better understand the question. and analyze the role of these contents.

To answer the question about the company that owned the spaceship Red Dwarf, we can extract and analyze relevant content from the provided passages. The key points are:

1. **Ownership of Red Dwarf**: The spaceship Red Dwarf is owned by the **Jupiter Mining Corporation (JMC)**. This information is explicitly stated in multiple passages, including the first passage and the fifth bullet point.

2. **Corporate Changes**: There is a mention of a corporate takeover where **M-Corp**, a large multi-national conglomerate, purchases the Jupiter Mining Corporation. This is significant because it indicates that while the JMC originally owned Red Dwarf, its ownership changed due to corporate acquisition. This is highlighted in the second and fourth passages.

3. **Context of the Series**: The series "Red Dwarf" is a British science fiction comedy that aired from 1988 to 1999 and has continued in various forms since then. Understanding the context of the show helps frame the significance of the spaceship and its ownership within the narrative. The passages provide background on the show's premise, characters, and the nature of the spaceship itself, which is described as a mining vessel.

### Analysis of the Role of These Contents:

- **Clarifying Ownership**: The repeated mention of the Jupiter Mining Corporation establishes it as the primary owner of Red Dwarf, which is crucial for understanding the show's setting and plot dynamics. The transition to M-Corp ownership introduces themes of corporate influence and change, which may be relevant to the show's satire of corporate culture.

- **Narrative Development**: The mention of the ship being a mining vessel and its operational context (e.g., mining asteroids) adds depth to the understanding of the ship's purpose and the characters' roles within the story. It sets the stage for the comedic and often absurd situations that arise from the interactions between the crew and their corporate overlords.

- **Cultural Context**: Knowing that "Red Dwarf" is a cult classic helps frame the significance of the spaceship and its ownership within a broader cultural context. The show's humor and themes resonate with audiences familiar with corporate satire, science fiction tropes, and British comedy.

In summary, the extracted content provides essential background knowledge about the ownership of Red Dwarf, the corporate dynamics at play, and the cultural context of the series, all of which are relevant to answering the question about the company that owned the spaceship.

answer:
Reasoning process: In the context of the British science fiction sitcom "Red Dwarf," the spaceship Red Dwarf is owned by a fictional mining company. The name of this company is mentioned throughout the series as the entity that operates the spaceship and employs the crew. 

Answer: Space Corps.

### Knowledge Enhanced Inference Process:

To accurately answer the question regarding the company that owned the spaceship Red Dwarf, we need to clarify the ownership details and the context surrounding the spaceship within the narrative of the British science fiction sitcom "Red Dwarf."

1. **Primary Ownership**: The spaceship Red Dwarf is owned by the **Jupiter Mining Corporation (JMC)**. This is a key detail that is consistently referenced throughout the series, establishing JMC as the primary entity responsible for the operation of the spaceship and the employment of its crew.

2. **Corporate Dynamics**: The series introduces a significant plot point where the Jupiter Mining Corporation is acquired by **M-Corp**, a large multi-national conglomerate. This transition is important as it reflects themes of corporate takeover and the impact of corporate culture on the crew and their environment. The mention of M-Corp indicates a shift in ownership and possibly in the operational dynamics of the ship.

3. **Contextual Understanding**: "Red Dwarf" is set in a comedic science fiction universe where the spaceship serves as a mining vessel. Understanding the context of the show, which aired from 1988 to 1999 and has continued in various formats, helps frame the significance of the spaceship and its ownership. The show combines humor with social commentary, particularly on corporate practices and human relationships in a futuristic setting.

4. **Narrative Implications**: The ownership by JMC and the subsequent acquisition by M-Corp are not just background details; they are integral to the plot and character development. The crew's interactions with their corporate overlords and the absurd situations that arise from these dynamics contribute to the show's comedic elements.

5. **Cultural Relevance**: Recognizing that "Red Dwarf" has gained a cult following adds another layer of understanding. The show's blend of humor, science fiction, and commentary on corporate life resonates with audiences, making the ownership of the spaceship a relevant aspect of its narrative.

### Answer:
The spaceship Red Dwarf is owned by the **Jupiter Mining Corporation (JMC)**. Later in the series, it is revealed that JMC is acquired by **M-Corp**, a large multi-national conglomerate.

### Knowledge Enhanced Inference Process:

In the context of the British science fiction sitcom "Red Dwarf," the spaceship Red Dwarf is owned by a fictional mining company. The correct name of this company is the **Jupiter Mining Corporation (JMC)**, which is explicitly mentioned in multiple passages. This foundational detail establishes the corporate entity responsible for the ship's operations and the employment of the crew.

1. **Ownership**: The primary ownership of the spaceship is attributed to the Jupiter Mining Corporation (JMC), which is crucial for understanding the operational context of the ship and its crew.

2. **Corporate Evolution**: The narrative evolves as the JMC is later acquired by a larger conglomerate known as **M-Corp**. This transition reflects themes of corporate influence and consumerism, which are prevalent in the series.

3. **Character Dynamics**: The crew, including characters like **Arnold Rimmer** and **Dave Lister**, interact with the ship and its systems, showcasing their roles and the comedic elements that arise from their situations. Rimmer, despite being a hologram, assumes a leadership role, which adds complexity to the character dynamics aboard the ship.

4. **Functionality of the Ship**: The "Red Dwarf" is characterized as an enormous mining vessel, primarily engaged in resource extraction from asteroids and moons. This operational focus is significant as it drives the plot and the adventures of the crew.

5. **Technological Aspects**: The ship's systems are managed by a computer named **Holly**, whose functionality fluctuates throughout the series. Holly's role adds both comedic and dramatic elements, influencing the crew's experiences.

6. **Cultural References**: The series incorporates various cultural elements, such as the use of Esperanto in early episodes, which enhances the show's unique blend of humor and science fiction.

By synthesizing this information, it becomes clear that the ownership of the spaceship "Red Dwarf" is a central aspect of the show's narrative, influencing character interactions, plot developments, and thematic explorations. The Jupiter Mining Corporation serves as a critical backdrop for the events that unfold, while the later acquisition by M-Corp introduces additional layers of commentary on corporate culture.

### Answer:
The name of the company that owned the spaceship Red Dwarf is the **Jupiter Mining Corporation (JMC)**.

Asteroids have presumably been mined for at least several decades, as Dave Lister is once heard singing a futuristic version of "Clementine" – ""On an asteroid / Evacuating for a mine / Lived an old plutonium miner / And his daughter Clementine..."". The Jupiter Mining Corporation, which operates the ship Red Dwarf, presumably mines on asteroids (Red Dwarf itself mined the Neptunian moon Triton, according to the novels).
', 'BULLET::::- "Red Dwarf" - spaceship from the same named BBC sci-fi comedy series "Red Dwarf"
', '"Red Dwarf" is a British comedy franchise which primarily comprises twelve series (the ninth being a mini-series) of a television science fiction sitcom that aired on BBC Two between 1988 and 1993 and from 1997 to 1999, and on Dave in 2009 and 2012 and from 2016 to the present, gaining a cult following. The series was created by Rob Grant and Doug Naylor.
', '"Red Dwarf" has a large complement of shuttles, including "Starbugs" and "Blue Midgets". Another shuttle type only mentioned in the novels but never so much as mentioned on the television series is "White Giant". The first episode, "The End", mentions that "Red Dwarf" has botanical gardens, when third-class technician Dave Lister and second-class technician Arnold Rimmer are sent off to repair a "faulty power circuit" there.
', 'In "Psirens" (1993), Kryten explains that "Red Dwarf" was "stolen", with the crew now based inside the shuttlecraft "Starbug" chasing after "Red Dwarf" to recover it.
']

Please extract content from these passages that can help enhance the model's causal reasoning and logical inference abilities.
consolidate these contents, and analyze how the selected information may impact the improvement of the model's causal reasoning and logical inference capabilities.

To enhance the model's causal reasoning and logical inference abilities, we can extract and consolidate key information from the provided passages regarding the spaceship "Red Dwarf" and its ownership. Here’s a breakdown of the relevant content:

### Extracted Information:
1. **Ownership of Red Dwarf**: 
   - The spaceship "Red Dwarf" is owned by the **Jupiter Mining Corporation (JMC)**.
   - In a later development, the parent company of "Red Dwarf," the Jupiter Mining Corporation, is purchased by **M-Corp**, which is described as the universe's largest multi-national conglomerate.

2. **Contextual Details**:
   - The ship is an enormous mining vessel, indicating its primary function and the nature of its operations.
   - The series features various characters, including Captain Frank Hollister and Second Technician Arnold Rimmer, who play significant roles in the narrative surrounding the ship.
   - The ship's systems are controlled by a computer named Holly, which adds a layer of complexity to the ship's operations and interactions.

3. **Cultural and Narrative Elements**:
   - The series is a British science fiction comedy that has gained a cult following, which may influence how the information is perceived and understood by audiences.
   - The ship's design and operational characteristics (e.g., described as a "gigantic red trash can") contribute to its identity within the narrative.

### Analysis of Impact on Causal Reasoning and Logical Inference:
1. **Understanding Ownership Dynamics**:
   - The transition of ownership from JMC to M-Corp introduces a causal relationship that can be analyzed. For instance, one can infer that the acquisition by M-Corp may lead to changes in the ship's operations, crew dynamics, or the introduction of new technologies/products (as seen with the appearance of M-Corp products).

2. **Character Interactions and Consequences**:
   - The roles of characters like Rimmer and Hollister can be analyzed for their impact on the ship's operations and the unfolding narrative. Understanding how these characters interact with the ship and each other can enhance the model's ability to infer outcomes based on character actions and decisions.

3. **Operational Characteristics**:
   - The ship's function as a mining vessel allows for reasoning about the implications of its operations (e.g., mining asteroids, resource management). This can lead to inferences about the economic and environmental impacts within the narrative universe.

4. **Narrative Structure**:
   - The comedic and science fiction elements of the series provide a unique context for reasoning. Understanding how humor and science fiction tropes interact can help the model infer character motivations and plot developments in similar narratives.

### Conclusion:
By consolidating the information regarding the ownership, operational characteristics, and narrative context of "Red Dwarf," the model can improve its causal reasoning and logical inference capabilities. This enhancement comes from understanding the relationships between entities (like ownership changes), character dynamics, and the implications of the ship's functions within the broader narrative. Such reasoning can be applied to analyze other similar narratives, improving the model's versatility and depth in understanding complex storylines.

answer:

cognition.content:
Fact-checking refers to the process of confirming the accuracy of a statement or claim through various sources or methods. 
This process aims to ensure that statements or claims are based on reliable and verifiable information while eliminating inaccurate or misleading content. 
Fact-checking may involve the examination of data, literature, expert opinions, or other trustworthy sources.
In the context of artificial intelligence, model illusion refers to the overconfidence response of the AI. 
When a model exhibits an 'illusion' (a tendency to output deceptive data), it indicates that the training data used by the model does not necessarily support the rationality of its outputs.
You are a scientist researching fact-checking and addressing model illusions in artificial intelligence. 
To answer the following question:
What is the name of the company that owned the spaceship Red Dwarf?
I will provide you with several retrieved passages:
Passages:
['The eponymous spaceship Red Dwarf is an enormous mining vessel owned by the Jupiter Mining Corporation. In the first episode "The End" (1988), and in some episodes early in the series chronologically set before the first episode, it is commanded by Captain Frank Hollister. For most of the show, Second Technician Arnold Rimmer is the self-imposed commander of this ship following the captain\'s off screen death in "The End", despite Rimmer being a deceased hologram. Holly says in both "Me²" (1988) and "Thanks for the Memory" (1988) that the ship has enough food and drink to last 30,000 years, but in "Thanks for the Memory" he says they have run out of Shake n\' Vac, and in "Me²", he claims there is only one After Eight mint left, and everyone is too polite to take it. In the novel "" (1989), the ship is described as being 6 miles (10\xa0km) long, 4 miles (6.5\xa0km) tall, and 3 miles (5\xa0km) wide. However, in the episode "DNA" (1991), the Cat describes the ship as being 5 miles (8\xa0km) long. The jagged shape and dull red colour of the vessel has led to the vessel being described in the episode "Psirens" (1993) as a "gigantic red trash can". All of "Red Dwarf"s systems are controlled by the computer Holly, although in "" (2009), Holly is depicted as being non-functioning after being washed out by a nine-year-overflowing bath, and is still evidently non-functioning as of "Twentica" (2016). The last mention of Holly is in "Fathers and Suns" (2012) when Kryten mentions that he misses him. In Series X the ship is instead run by the JMC On-Board Computer in Holly\'s absence. The On-Board Computer is not a character but rather an automated system that does not seem to have artificial intelligence and behaves as if the ship is still fully staffed and operating normally, at one point even threatening to demote Rimmer for not showing up to work in three million years.\n', 'The crew return to the sleeping quarters to watch the updates install, and following it reaching 100%, a message broadcasts informing them a large corporation known as M-Corp has purchased "Red Dwarf\'s" parent company, the Jupiter Mining Corporation (JMC). Instantly, new M-Corp-owned products appear, including microwaves, TVs, beer, and more. As Rimmer and Kryten begin taking some of the equipment back to the science room, Lister and Cat examine the new M-Corp lager which Lister goes to put in their fridge, only to discover the Leopard Lager in there previously has disappeared. When questioned on the fridge\'s apparent lack of lager, Cat bluntly tells him its there before taking out a seemingly-invisible lager, shaking it, and getting it all over a disbelieving Lister.\n', 'BULLET::::- 1980s: The British science fiction comedy "Red Dwarf" (which first began in 1988), is set on a bilingual spaceship where the signs on the walls are written in both English and Esperanto (for example, the corridor on each level is labelled "Level/Nivelo [###]", and a sign in a movie theatre says "Cinema/Kinejo") – but this only lasted for the first two series, when a redesign of the sets eliminated the Esperanto. Only one episode of the show (Series 2 episode 1, "Kryten") actually features a significant amount of Esperanto being spoken: in which the character of Rimmer is attempting to learn Esperanto from an instructional video and failing miserably (although his underachieving bunkmate Lister can understand it perfectly). In a later episode (Series 5 episode 6, "Back to Reality"), aired in 1992, the crew encounter an "ocean seeding ship" named the "SSS Esperanto". Later, when their entire lives are revealed, falsely, to have all been a computer game, the Esperanto translation of Esperanto as "One Who Hopes" is said to have been a clue to use that ship\'s functioning lasers to defeat the "Despair Squid".\n', 'After "Red Dwarf" receives a long-overdue software update, the crew learn their employer has been purchased in a takeover by M-Corp, the universe\'s largest multi-national conglomerate.\n', 'BULLET::::- In the series "Red Dwarf", the titular ship belongs to the Jupiter Mining Corporation, and there are many references to Jupiter and its moons (for example Arnold Rimmer is originally from Io).\n', 'BULLET::::- "Red Dwarf" (1988–1999), television series. Asteroids have presumably been mined for at least several decades, as Dave Lister is once heard singing a futuristic version of "Clementine" – ""On an asteroid / Evacuating for a mine / Lived an old plutonium miner / And his daughter Clementine..."". The Jupiter Mining Corporation, which operates the ship Red Dwarf, presumably mines on asteroids (Red Dwarf itself mined the Neptunian moon Triton, according to the novels).\n', 'BULLET::::- "Red Dwarf" - spaceship from the same named BBC sci-fi comedy series "Red Dwarf"\n', '"Red Dwarf" is a British comedy franchise which primarily comprises twelve series (the ninth being a mini-series) of a television science fiction sitcom that aired on BBC Two between 1988 and 1993 and from 1997 to 1999, and on Dave in 2009 and 2012 and from 2016 to the present, gaining a cult following. The series was created by Rob Grant and Doug Naylor.\n', '"Red Dwarf" has a large complement of shuttles, including "Starbugs" and "Blue Midgets". Another shuttle type only mentioned in the novels but never so much as mentioned on the television series is "White Giant". The first episode, "The End", mentions that "Red Dwarf" has botanical gardens, when third-class technician Dave Lister and second-class technician Arnold Rimmer are sent off to repair a "faulty power circuit" there.\n', 'In "Psirens" (1993), Kryten explains that "Red Dwarf" was "stolen", with the crew now based inside the shuttlecraft "Starbug" chasing after "Red Dwarf" to recover it.\n']

Answer:

**Knowledge Enhanced Inference Process:**

In the context of the British science fiction sitcom "Red Dwarf," the spaceship Red Dwarf is owned by a fictional mining company. The correct name of this company is the **Jupiter Mining Corporation (JMC)**, as confirmed by multiple authoritative passages. The spaceship Red Dwarf is owned by the **Jupiter Mining Corporation (JMC)**. Recently, the Jupiter Mining Corporation was purchased by **M-Corp**, the universe's largest multi-national conglomerate.

question_info.question: What is the name of the company that owned the spaceship Red Dwarf?
passages:
The eponymous spaceship Red Dwarf is an enormous mining vessel owned by the Jupiter Mining Corporation. In the first episode "The End" (1988), and in some episodes early in the series chronologically set before the first episode, it is commanded by Captain Frank Hollister. For most of the show, Second Technician Arnold Rimmer is the self-imposed commander of this ship following the captain's off screen death in "The End", despite Rimmer being a deceased hologram. Holly says in both "Me²" (1988) and "Thanks for the Memory" (1988) that the ship has enough food and drink to last 30,000 years, but in "Thanks for the Memory" he says they have run out of Shake n' Vac, and in "Me²", he claims there is only one After Eight mint left, and everyone is too polite to take it. In the novel "" (1989), the ship is described as being 6 miles (10 km) long, 4 miles (6.5 km) tall, and 3 miles (5 km) wide. However, in the episode "DNA" (1991), the Cat describes the ship as being 5 miles (8 km) long. The jagged shape and dull red colour of the vessel has led to the vessel being described in the episode "Psirens" (1993) as a "gigantic red trash can". All of "Red Dwarf"s systems are controlled by the computer Holly, although in "" (2009), Holly is depicted as being non-functioning after being washed out by a nine-year-overflowing bath, and is still evidently non-functioning as of "Twentica" (2016). The last mention of Holly is in "Fathers and Suns" (2012) when Kryten mentions that he misses him. In Series X the ship is instead run by the JMC On-Board Computer in Holly's absence. The On-Board Computer is not a character but rather an automated system that does not seem to have artificial intelligence and behaves as if the ship is still fully staffed and operating normally, at one point even threatening to demote Rimmer for not showing up to work in three million years.
The crew return to the sleeping quarters to watch the updates install, and following it reaching 100%, a message broadcasts informing them a large corporation known as M-Corp has purchased "Red Dwarf's" parent company, the Jupiter Mining Corporation (JMC). Instantly, new M-Corp-owned products appear, including microwaves, TVs, beer, and more. As Rimmer and Kryten begin taking some of the equipment back to the science room, Lister and Cat examine the new M-Corp lager which Lister goes to put in their fridge, only to discover the Leopard Lager in there previously has disappeared. When questioned on the fridge's apparent lack of lager, Cat bluntly tells him its there before taking out a seemingly-invisible lager, shaking it, and getting it all over a disbelieving Lister.
BULLET::::- 1980s: The British science fiction comedy "Red Dwarf" (which first began in 1988), is set on a bilingual spaceship where the signs on the walls are written in both English and Esperanto (for example, the corridor on each level is labelled "Level/Nivelo [###]", and a sign in a movie theatre says "Cinema/Kinejo") – but this only lasted for the first two series, when a redesign of the sets eliminated the Esperanto. Only one episode of the show (Series 2 episode 1, "Kryten") actually features a significant amount of Esperanto being spoken: in which the character of Rimmer is attempting to learn Esperanto from an instructional video and failing miserably (although his underachieving bunkmate Lister can understand it perfectly). In a later episode (Series 5 episode 6, "Back to Reality"), aired in 1992, the crew encounter an "ocean seeding ship" named the "SSS Esperanto". Later, when their entire lives are revealed, falsely, to have all been a computer game, the Esperanto translation of Esperanto as "One Who Hopes" is said to have been a clue to use that ship's functioning lasers to defeat the "Despair Squid".
After "Red Dwarf" receives a long-overdue software update, the crew learn their employer has been purchased in a takeover by M-Corp, the universe's largest multi-national conglomerate.
BULLET::::- In the series "Red Dwarf", the titular ship belongs to the Jupiter Mining Corporation, and there are many references to Jupiter and its moons (for example Arnold Rimmer is originally from Io).
BULLET::::- "Red Dwarf" (1988–1999), television series. Asteroids have presumably been mined for at least several decades, as Dave Lister is once heard singing a futuristic version of "Clementine" – ""On an asteroid / Evacuating for a mine / Lived an old plutonium miner / And his daughter Clementine..."". The Jupiter Mining Corporation, which operates the ship Red Dwarf, presumably mines on asteroids (Red Dwarf itself mined the Neptunian moon Triton, according to the novels).
BULLET::::- "Red Dwarf" - spaceship from the same named BBC sci-fi comedy series "Red Dwarf"
"Red Dwarf" is a British comedy franchise which primarily comprises twelve series (the ninth being a mini-series) of a television science fiction sitcom that aired on BBC Two between 1988 and 1993 and from 1997 to 1999, and on Dave in 2009 and 2012 and from 2016 to the present, gaining a cult following. The series was created by Rob Grant and Doug Naylor.
"Red Dwarf" has a large complement of shuttles, including "Starbugs" and "Blue Midgets". Another shuttle type only mentioned in the novels but never so much as mentioned on the television series is "White Giant". The first episode, "The End", mentions that "Red Dwarf" has botanical gardens, when third-class technician Dave Lister and second-class technician Arnold Rimmer are sent off to repair a "faulty power circuit" there.
In "Psirens" (1993), Kryten explains that "Red Dwarf" was "stolen", with the crew now based inside the shuttlecraft "Starbug" chasing after "Red Dwarf" to recover it.
